levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising common prefixes and suffixes and knowing that they change the meaning of a root word.
levels.example_task: Add the correct prefix (un-, dis-, re-, mis-) to complete each word: ___happy, ___appear, ___write, ___lead.
levels.example_response: unhappy, disappear, rewrite, mislead
common_errors: Using the wrong prefix ('dishappy' instead of 'unhappy')
Not understanding what the prefix means

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Applying Year 3-4 prefix and suffix spelling rules, including the in-/il-/im-/ir- variants meaning 'not'.
levels.example_task: Add the correct version of the 'not' prefix to each word: ___legal, ___possible, ___regular, ___complete.
levels.example_response: illegal, impossible, irregular, incomplete. The prefix changes to match the first letter of the root word.
common_errors: Writing 'inlegal' instead of 'illegal'
Not recognising that all four prefixes share the same meaning

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Applying all Years 3-4 prefix and suffix spelling rules accurately in independent writing, including the -ation ending and suffix changes at word junctions.
levels.example_task: Write the correct spelling when these suffixes are added: inform + ation, happy + ness, hope + ful, fame + ous.
levels.example_response: information, happiness, hopeful, famous. For happiness, the 'y' changes to 'i' before adding '-ness'. For famous, the 'e' is dropped before adding '-ous'.
common_errors: Writing 'happyness' (not changing y to i)
Writing 'fameous' (not dropping the e)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining the spelling rules for word junctions and applying them to unfamiliar words, including identifying exceptions.
levels.example_task: Explain why 'hoping' drops the 'e' but 'hopeful' keeps it. Then apply the same rule to: care + ing, care + ful, notice + able.
levels.example_response: When adding a suffix that starts with a vowel (-ing), the final 'e' is dropped: hoping. When adding a suffix that starts with a consonant (-ful), the 'e' is kept: hopeful. So: caring (drop e, vowel suffix), careful (keep e, consonant suffix). But noticeable is an exception — the 'e' is kept before -able to preserve the soft 'c' sound. Without the 'e', it would be pronounced 'notickable'.
common_errors: Not knowing the exceptions (noticeable, changeable)
Stating the rule without understanding the phonological reason behind exceptions

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising that some words double the final consonant before adding a vowel suffix.
levels.example_task: Which is correct: 'runing' or 'running'? 'hoping' or 'hopping'? Explain the difference.
levels.example_response: Running is correct (double n). Hopping has a double p because it comes from 'hop' (short vowel sound). Hoping has one p because it comes from 'hope' (long vowel sound with magic e).
common_errors: Not hearing the difference between short and long vowel sounds
Doubling when there is a silent e (writing 'hoppping')

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Applying the consonant doubling rule to one-syllable words with short vowels before adding vowel suffixes.
levels.example_task: Add -ing to these words: shop, sleep, swim, read, chat.
levels.example_response: shopping (short vowel, double p), sleeping (long vowel, no doubling), swimming (short vowel, double m), reading (long vowel, no doubling), chatting (short vowel, double t).
common_errors: Doubling when the vowel is long ('sleepping')
Not doubling when the vowel is short ('shoping')

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Applying the doubling rule to polysyllabic words, understanding the stressed syllable principle: double if the final syllable is stressed.
levels.example_task: Add -ed to these words: forget, visit, prefer, garden, begin.
levels.example_response: forgotten/forgot → forgetting (stress on 'get', double t), visited (stress on 'vis', no doubling), preferred (stress on 'fer', double r), gardened (stress on 'gar', no doubling), beginning (stress on 'gin', double n).
common_errors: Doubling in 'visited' → 'visitted' (unstressed final syllable)
Not hearing which syllable is stressed

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining the doubling rule by reference to stressed and unstressed syllables, and applying it to unfamiliar words.
levels.example_task: A friend writes 'benefitting' and 'occuring'. Are these correct? Explain the rule they need.
levels.example_response: 'Benefitting' — the stress in 'benefit' falls on 'ben', not 'fit', so by the rule we should NOT double: 'benefiting' is correct (though 'benefitting' is accepted in British English, which is confusing!). 'Occuring' is wrong — the stress in 'occur' falls on 'cur', so we MUST double: 'occurring'. The rule is: if the stress falls on the last syllable and it ends in a single consonant after a single vowel, double it.
common_errors: Not being able to identify where stress falls in a polysyllabic word
Applying the rule mechanically without checking stress placement

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Identifying homophones as words that sound the same but have different spellings and meanings.
levels.example_task: Match each word to its correct meaning: there/their/they're. Fill in: ___ coats are on the floor. Put them over ___. ___ going to be late.
levels.example_response: Their coats are on the floor (belonging to them). Put them over there (a place). They're going to be late (they are).
common_errors: Confusing 'their' and 'there'
Not understanding that 'they're' is a contraction of 'they are'

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Spelling common homophones correctly in sentence contexts, using meaning to select the right spelling.
levels.example_task: Choose the correct word: The (weather/whether) was terrible. I don't know (weather/whether) to go. (Whose/Who's) book is this? (Whose/Who's) coming to the party?
levels.example_response: The weather was terrible (the climate). I don't know whether to go (if). Whose book is this? (belonging to whom). Who's coming to the party? (who is).
common_errors: Confusing weather/whether because they sound identical
Not recognising that who's = who is

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Spelling all Years 3-4 homophones correctly in independent writing, using the meaning distinction to guide spelling choices.
levels.example_task: Write from dictation: 'They're going to accept the award, except for the one whose trophy was sent to the wrong address. It's not fair, but its handle was broken.'
levels.example_response: They're going to accept the award, except for the one whose trophy was sent to the wrong address. It's not fair, but its handle was broken.
common_errors: Writing 'accept' for 'except' or vice versa (the most commonly confused pair)
Writing 'it's' for possessive 'its' — one of the most persistent errors across all year groups

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining why English has homophones and using etymology to distinguish between them.
levels.example_task: Why are 'knight' and 'night' spelt differently even though they sound the same? Use what you know about word origins.
levels.example_response: They come from different origins and originally sounded different. 'Knight' comes from Old English 'cniht' (a young servant), and the 'k' was pronounced — people said 'k-nicht'. 'Night' comes from Old English 'niht'. Over time, English stopped pronouncing the 'k' and the 'gh' sound, but the spellings were kept. Homophones exist because English spelling preserves the history of words even after pronunciation has changed.
common_errors: Assuming homophones are a flaw in English rather than a result of language history
Making up etymological explanations rather than connecting to known patterns

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising that some spelling patterns come from other languages and do not follow typical English phonics rules.
levels.example_task: Read these words aloud: chef, machine, chorus, antique. Which ones do NOT follow the usual English spelling rules for those sounds?
levels.example_response: 'Chef' and 'machine' — the 'ch' makes a 'sh' sound, which is unusual. 'Chorus' — the 'ch' makes a 'k' sound. 'Antique' — the 'que' makes a 'k' sound. These words come from French or Greek.
common_errors: Trying to sound out the words using English phonics rules only
Not noticing that 'ch' can represent different sounds

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Spelling words with patterns from specific etymologies: ch as /k/ (Greek), ch as /sh/ (French), -gue/-que (French).
levels.example_task: Sort these words by their origin: chemist, parachute, unique, echo, brochure, technique, character, chauffeur.
levels.example_response: Greek ch = /k/: chemist, echo, character. French ch = /sh/: parachute, brochure, chauffeur. French -que: unique, technique.
common_errors: Misspelling Greek 'ch' words by writing 'kemist'
Confusing French and Greek 'ch' patterns

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Spelling words with a range of etymological patterns accurately, including -tion/-sion/-ssion/-cian, -ous, and sc for /s/.
levels.example_task: Write these words from dictation: musician, possession, television, science, scissors, marvellous, dangerous, information.
levels.example_response: musician, possession, television, science, scissors, marvellous, dangerous, information [all correct]
common_errors: Writing 'posession' (one s) instead of 'possession'
Writing 'sience' instead of 'science' (forgetting sc = /s/)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining why words from different languages follow different spelling conventions and using this knowledge to spell unfamiliar words by analogy.
levels.example_task: You encounter the word 'chronological' for the first time. Use your knowledge of Greek spelling patterns to spell it correctly and explain your reasoning.
levels.example_response: I would spell it 'chronological'. I know 'ch' from Greek makes a /k/ sound (like 'character' and 'chorus'). 'Chrono' means time (like in 'chronometer'). The '-logical' ending is common in Greek-origin words meaning 'the study of' (like 'biological', 'archaeological'). So the Greek origin tells me it starts with 'ch', not 'k' or 'cr'.
common_errors: Spelling it 'kronological' by using English phonics
Not connecting the Greek origin to the spelling pattern

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Spelling some high-frequency words from the Years 3-4 statutory list correctly in isolation.
levels.example_task: Spell these words: because, different, friend, again, people.
levels.example_response: because, different, friend, again, people [all correct]
common_errors: Writing 'becuase' or 'becouse'
Writing 'diffrent' (missing the second 'e')

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Spelling most Years 3-4 statutory words correctly in dictated sentences.
levels.example_task: Write from dictation: 'Although the experiment was difficult, the whole group decided to continue because the experience was important.'
levels.example_response: Although the experiment was difficult, the whole group decided to continue because the experience was important.
common_errors: Spelling 'although' as 'allthough'
Spelling 'experience' as 'expirence'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Spelling all Years 3-4 statutory words correctly in independent writing, demonstrating transfer from spelling practice to composition.
levels.example_task: Write a paragraph about a science experiment using at least six words from the Years 3-4 word list: experiment, different, group, particular, perhaps, suppose, knowledge, pressure.
levels.example_response: Our group carried out an experiment to test whether different materials could withstand pressure. We had particular expectations — we supposed that metal would be strongest. Perhaps our knowledge was correct, because the metal bar survived the greatest force.
common_errors: Spelling words correctly in the spelling test but reverting to errors in free writing
Avoiding difficult words by choosing simpler alternatives

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Identifying patterns within the statutory word list and using them to learn unfamiliar words by analogy.
levels.example_task: Find three words on the Years 3-4 list that share a tricky pattern. Explain the pattern and suggest a strategy for remembering them.
levels.example_response: 'Special', 'social' and 'official' all end in the '-cial' pattern where 'ci' makes a /sh/ sound. This comes from Latin. A strategy: if you hear /shul/ at the end of a word that comes after a vowel, try '-cial' first. You can also remember that 'special' has 'especially' in the same family, so the 'c' before 'i' is consistent across related words.
common_errors: Treating each word list word as completely separate rather than looking for patterns
Using mnemonics that are harder to remember than the word itself

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Understanding that an apostrophe before 's' shows something belongs to one person or thing.
levels.example_task: Rewrite using a possessive apostrophe: 'the tail belonging to the cat', 'the book belonging to James'.
levels.example_response: the cat's tail, James's book
common_errors: Writing 'the cats tail' (no apostrophe)
Confusing possessive 's' with plural 's'

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Placing the possessive apostrophe correctly with regular plural nouns ending in -s.
levels.example_task: Add the possessive apostrophe: 'the toys belonging to the girls', 'the kennel belonging to the dogs', 'the staffroom belonging to the teachers'.
levels.example_response: the girls' toys, the dogs' kennel, the teachers' staffroom. Because the nouns are already plural (ending in 's'), the apostrophe goes after the 's'.
common_errors: Writing 'the girl's toys' when meaning multiple girls
Adding an extra 's' after the apostrophe ('the girls's toys')

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Placing the possessive apostrophe correctly with both regular plurals (s') and irregular plurals ('s), understanding the rule.
levels.example_task: Add the possessive apostrophe: 'the playground belonging to the children', 'the changing room belonging to the women', 'the cheese belonging to the mice', 'the coats belonging to the boys'.
levels.example_response: the children's playground, the women's changing room, the mice's cheese, the boys' coats. For irregular plurals (children, women, mice) that don't end in 's', add 's. For regular plurals (boys) that already end in 's', just add an apostrophe.
common_errors: Writing 'the childrens' playground' (treating 'children' like a regular plural)
Not recognising that 'women' and 'mice' are irregular plurals

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining the possessive apostrophe rule clearly and identifying and correcting errors in a passage.
levels.example_task: Find and correct ALL the apostrophe errors in this passage: 'The dog's were playing in the park. One dogs ball rolled into the ladys garden. The childrens' teacher called them back.'
levels.example_response: 1. 'The dog's were playing' → 'The dogs were playing' (remove apostrophe — this is a simple plural, not possessive). 2. 'One dogs ball' → 'One dog's ball' (add apostrophe — the ball belongs to one dog). 3. 'the ladys garden' → 'the lady's garden' (add apostrophe — the garden belongs to the lady). 4. 'The childrens' teacher' → 'The children's teacher' (move apostrophe before the 's' — 'children' is already plural).
common_errors: Missing one of the errors
Correcting correctly but not being able to explain the rule behind each correction

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using a dictionary to check the spelling of a word they have attempted.
levels.example_task: You have written 'nessesary'. Use the dictionary to check if this is correct and find the right spelling.
levels.example_response: It's not under 'ness-'. I tried 'nec-' and found it: 'necessary'. I had the wrong letter — it's a 'c' not an 's' in the middle.
common_errors: Giving up after one failed attempt to find the word
Looking in the wrong section of the dictionary

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using the first two or three letters to locate words efficiently, trying alternative spellings when the first attempt fails.
levels.example_task: You want to check the spelling of 'psychology'. Your first guess is 'sychology'. How would you find it in the dictionary?
levels.example_response: I can't find it under 'S'. I know some words starting with a /s/ sound are actually spelt 'ps' (like 'psalm'). So I look under 'PS' and find 'psychology'.
common_errors: Not thinking of alternative initial letter combinations
Not knowing that 'ps-' is a possible spelling for /s/

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using a dictionary efficiently as part of the writing process to check and correct spellings, with sufficient speed that it does not disrupt writing flow.
levels.example_task: You are writing a report and want to use these words but are unsure of the spelling: 'environment', 'government', 'temperature'. Check all three in under two minutes.
levels.example_response: [Locates each word efficiently using guide words] environment — e-n-v section. government — g-o-v section. temperature — t-e-m section. All confirmed correct.
common_errors: Taking too long and losing the thread of their writing
Checking spelling but then not actually correcting the error in their work

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Choosing between dictionary, morphological analysis and etymological reasoning as spelling strategies, selecting the most efficient approach for each word.
levels.example_task: Which strategy would be quickest for checking each spelling: 'unbelievable', 'questionnaire', 'autobiography'? Explain why.
levels.example_response: 'Unbelievable' — morphology is fastest: un + believe + able. I know how to spell 'believe' and I know the suffix rules. 'Questionnaire' — dictionary is best because the double 'n' is not predictable from the root word. 'Autobiography' — etymology is fastest: auto (self) + bio (life) + graph (write) + y. If I know the Greek roots, I can build the spelling without looking it up.
common_errors: Always defaulting to the dictionary when a faster strategy exists
Not recognising which words require dictionary checking versus root analysis

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Writing a simple dictated sentence with correct spelling and basic punctuation.
levels.example_task: Write from dictation: 'The children played in the garden after school.'
levels.example_response: The children played in the garden after school.
common_errors: Missing the capital letter at the start
Spelling 'children' as 'childern'

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Writing dictated sentences that include Years 3-4 spelling words and commas.
levels.example_task: Write from dictation: 'Although it was a difficult experiment, the group continued because they believed the answer was important.'
levels.example_response: Although it was a difficult experiment, the group continued because they believed the answer was important.
common_errors: Missing the comma after 'Although it was a difficult experiment'
Spelling 'experiment' as 'expariment'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Writing dictated passages of 2-3 sentences including apostrophes, direct speech punctuation and varied sentence structures.
levels.example_task: Write from dictation: 'The teacher asked, "Whose idea was this?" Nobody answered. Eventually, the children's spokesperson stood up and said, "It was a group decision."'
levels.example_response: The teacher asked, "Whose idea was this?" Nobody answered. Eventually, the children's spokesperson stood up and said, "It was a group decision."
common_errors: Missing speech marks around the direct speech
Writing 'who's' instead of 'whose'

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Writing dictated passages with complex grammar and punctuation, self-checking and correcting errors before the teacher reveals the correct version.
levels.example_task: Write from dictation, then check your own work before I show the answer: 'Before the experiment began, the scientist's assistant carefully measured the different liquids. "Are you certain these quantities are accurate?" she asked.'
levels.example_response: [Writes passage, then self-checks] I need to check: 'scientist's' has an apostrophe because the assistant belongs to the scientist. 'different' — d-i-f-f-e-r-e-n-t, yes. 'accurate' — double c, yes. Speech marks around the question, question mark inside the speech marks, comma after 'accurate?' — no wait, no comma needed because the speech ends with a question mark. 'she asked' — lowercase 's'.
common_errors: Not self-checking before the reveal
Focusing on spelling but missing punctuation errors, or vice versa
